rules.description:
*Checks whether !isEmpty can be replaced with nonEmpty.*

!.isEmpty can be replaced with.nonEmpty to make it easier to reason about.
rules.name: !isEmpty can be replaced with nonEmpty

rules.description:
*Checks whether !nonEmpty can be replaced with isEmpty.*

!.nonEmpty can be replaced with.isEmpty to make it easier to reason about.
rules.name: !nonEmpty can be replaced with isEmpty

rules.description:
*Checks for comparison of arrays using == which will always return false.*

Array equals is not an equality check. Use a.deep == b.deep or convert to another collection type.
rules.name: Array equals

rules.description:
*Checks for arrays passed to String.format.*

An Array passed to String.format might result in an incorrect formatting.
rules.name: Array passed to String.format

rules.description:
*Checks for ranges using (j to k - 1).*

A range in the following format (j to k - 1) can be simplified to (j until k).
rules.name: Avoid (j to k - 1)

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Traversable.size.*

.size can be slow for some data structures, prefer .nonEmpty, which is O(1).
rules.name: Avoid Traversable.size != 0

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Traversable.size.*

Traversable.size can be slow for some data structures, prefer Traversable.isEmpty, which is O(1).
rules.name: Avoid Traversable.size == 0

rules.description:
*Checks for symbolic method names.*

Scala style guide advocates against routinely using operators as method names, see http://docs.scala-lang.org/style/naming-conventions.html#symbolic-method-names.
rules.name: Avoid operator overload

rules.description:
*Checks for use of BigDecimal(double) which can be unsafe.*

The results of this constructor can be somewhat unpredictable. E.g. writing new BigDecimal(0.1) in Java creates a BigDecimal which is actually equal to 0.1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This is because 0.1 cannot be represented exactly as a double.
rules.name: Big decimal double constructor

rules.description:
*Checks for use of setScale() on a BigDecimal without setting the rounding mode can throw an exception.*

When using setScale() on a BigDecimal without setting the rounding mode, this can throw an exception if rounding is required. Did you mean to call setScale(s, RoundingMode.XYZ)?
rules.name: BigDecimal setScale() without rounding mode

rules.description:
*Checks for types with upper bounds of a final type.*

Pointless type bound. Type parameter can only be a single value.
rules.name: Bounded by a final type

rules.description:
*Checks for potentially broken odd checks.*

Code that attempts to check for oddness using x % 2 == 1 will fail on negative numbers. Consider using x % 2 != 0
rules.name: Broken odd check

rules.description:
*Checks for try blocks that catch exception.*

Did you intend to catch all exceptions? Consider catching a more specific exception class.
rules.name: Catch exception

rules.description:
*Checks for try blocks that catch fatal exceptions: VirtualMachineError, ThreadDeath, InterruptedException, LinkageError, ControlThrowable.*

Did you intend to catch a fatal exception? Consider using scala.util.control.NonFatal instead.
rules.name: Catch fatal exception

rules.description:
*Checks for try blocks that catch Throwable.*

Did you intend to catch all throwables? Consider catching a more specific exception class.
rules.name: Catch throwable

rules.description:
*Checks for try blocks that catch null pointer exceptions.*

Avoid using null at all cost and you shouldn't need to catch NullPointerExceptions. Prefer Option to indicate potentially missing values and use Try to materialize exceptions thrown by any external libraries.
rules.name: Catching NPE

rules.description:
*Ensures class names adhere to the style guidelines.*

Class names should begin with uppercase letter.
rules.name: Class name not recommended

rules.description:
*Checks for negative access on a sequence, e.g. list.get(-1).*

Trying to access Seq elements using a negative index will result in an IndexOutOfBoundsException.
rules.name: Collection index out of bounds

rules.description:
*Checks for variables that are confusingly named.*

E.g. an instance of a Set is confusingly referred to by a variable called/containing list, or the other way around.
rules.name: Collection naming confusion

rules.description:
*Checks for collection operations that promote the collection to Any.*

The :+ (append) operator on collections accepts any argument you give it, which means that you can end up with e.g. Seq[Any] if your types don't match.
rules.name: Collection promotion to Any

rules.description:
*Checks for equality comparisons that cannot succeed.*

In most case comparing unrelated types cannot succeed and it's usually an indication of a bug.
rules.name: Comparing unrelated types

rules.description:
*Checks for equality checks with itself.*

Comparison with self will always yield true.
rules.name: Comparision with self

rules.description:
*Checks for code like a == List() or a == Nil.*

Prefer use of isEmpty instead of comparison to an empty List.
rules.name: Comparison to empty list

rules.description:
*Checks for code like a == Set() or a == Set.empty.*

Prefer use of isEmpty instead of comparison to an empty Set.
rules.name: Comparison to empty set

rules.description:
*Checks for code where the if condition compiles to a constant.*

An if condition which gets compiled to a constant, like e.g. if (1 < 2) or if (false) doesn't add any value and should be avoided.
rules.name: Constant if expression

rules.description:
*Checks for division by one.*

Divide by one will always return the original value.
rules.name: Divide by one

rules.description:
*Checks for code like !(!b).*

Double negation can be removed, e.g. !(!b) it equal to just b.
rules.name: Double negation

rules.description:
*Checks for duplicate import statements.*

Duplicate imports should be removed.
rules.name: Duplicate import

rules.description:
*Checks for duplicate key names in Map literals.*

A map key is overwritten by a later entry.
rules.name: Duplicated map key

rules.description:
*Checks for duplicate values in set literals.*

A set value is overwritten by a later entry.
rules.name: Duplicated set value

rules.description:
*Checks for empty case classes like, e.g. case class Faceman().*

An empty case class can be rewritten as a case object.
rules.name: Empty case class

rules.description:
*Finds catch blocks that don't handle caught exceptions.*

If you use a try/catch block to deal with an exception, you should handle all of the caught exceptions and if for some reason you're throwing another exception in the result, you should include the original exception as the cause.
rules.name: Empty catch block

rules.description:
*Checks for empty for loops.*

An empty for loop isn't a common practice and in most cases is considered as dead code.
rules.name: Empty for loop

rules.description:
*Checks for empty if blocks.*

An empty if block is considered as dead code.
rules.name: Empty if expression

rules.description:
*Looks for interpolated strings that have no arguments.*

String declared as interpolated but has no parameters can be turned into a regular string.
rules.name: Empty interpolated string

rules.description:
*Checks for empty method statements.*

An empty method is considered as dead code.
rules.name: Empty method

rules.description:
*Checks for empty synchronized blocks.*

An empty synchronized block is considered as dead code.
rules.name: Empty synchronized block

rules.description:
*Checks for empty try blocks.*

An empty try block is considered as dead code.
rules.name: Empty try block

rules.description:
*Checks for empty while blocks.*

An empty while block is considered as dead code.
rules.name: Empty while block

rules.description:
*Checks if exists() can be simplified to contains().*

exists(x => x == y) can be replaced with contains(y).
rules.name: Exists simplifiable to contains

rules.description:
*Checks for overridden finalizers that do not call super.*

Finalizers should call super.finalize() to ensure superclasses are able to run their finalization logic.
rules.name: Finalizer without super

rules.description:
*Checks for equality checks on floating point types.*

Due to minor rounding errors, it is not advisable to compare floating-point numbers using the == operator. Either use a threshold based comparison, or switch to a BigDecimal.
rules.name: Floating type comparison

rules.description:
*Checks for invalid format strings.*

An unchecked exception will be thrown when a format string contains an illegal syntax or a format specifier that is incompatible with the given arguments.
rules.name: Illegal format string

rules.description:
*Checks for code like option.size > 1.*

Option.size > 1 can never be true, did you mean to use Option.nonEmpty instead?
rules.name: Impossible Option.size condition

rules.description:
*Checks for wrong number of arguments to String.format.*

The number of arguments passed to String.format doesn't correspond to the number of fields in the format string.
rules.name: Incorrect number of args for format

rules.description:
*Checks for exceptions that are not called *Exception and vice versa.*

Class named exception does not derive from Exception / class derived from Exception is not named *Exception.
rules.name: Incorrectly named exceptions

rules.description:
*Checks for expressions like x % 1.*

Any expression x % 1 will always return 0.
rules.name: Integer mod one

rules.description:
*Checks for invalid regex literals.*

Invalid regex literals can fail at compile time with a PatternSyntaxException. This could be caused by e.g. dangling meta characters, or unclosed escape characters, etc.
rules.name: Invalid regex

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Java conversions.*

Use of Java conversions can lead to unusual behaviour. It is recommended to use JavaConverters.
rules.name: Java conversions

rules.description:
*Checks for when elements are appended to a list.*

List append is O(n). For large lists, consider using cons (::) or another data structure such as ListBuffer, Vector or a cats.data.Chain (which has constant prepend and append).
rules.name: List append is slow

rules.description:
*Checks for use of List.size.*

List.size is O(n). Consider using a different data type with O(1) size lookup such as Vector or an Array.
rules.name: List.size is O(n)

rules.description:
*Checks for sealed traits without any classes extending it.*

A sealed trait that is not extended is considered dead code.
rules.name: Lonely sealed trait

rules.description:
*Checks for strings that look like they should be interpolated.*

Did you forget to prefix this string with an s, f or raw to interpolate it?
rules.name: Looks like interpolated String

rules.description:
*Warns when you could use a partial function directly instead of a match block.*

A map match can be replaced with a partial function for greater readability.
rules.name: Match instead of a partial function

rules.description:
*Checks for methods that have over 10 parameters.*

Methods having a large number of parameters are more difficult to reason about, consider refactoring this code.
rules.name: Max parameters

rules.description:
*Warns on method names that don't adhere to the Scala style guidelines.*

Methods should be in camelCase style with the first letter lower-case. See http://docs.scala-lang.org/style/naming-conventions.html#methods.
rules.name: Method name not recommended

rules.description:
*Checks for functions that are defined or inferred to return Any.*

Method returns Any. Consider using a more specialized type.
rules.name: Method returning Any

rules.description:
*Checks for case classes without a final modifier.*

Using case classes without final modifier can lead to surprising breakage.
rules.name: Missing final modifier on case class

rules.description:
*Checks for x == Double.NaN which will always fail.*

NaN comparison will always fail. Use value.isNan instead.
rules.name: Nan comparison

rules.description:
*Checks for code that overrides parent method but simply calls super.*

This method is overridden yet only calls super.
rules.name: Noop override

rules.description:
*Checks for use of null in assignments.*

Use an Option instead when the value can be empty.
rules.name: Null assignment

rules.description:
*Checks for use of null in method invocation.*

Use an Option instead when the value can be empty and pass down a None instead.
rules.name: Null parameter

rules.description:
*Ensures object names adhere to the Scala style guidelines.*

Object names should only contain alphanumeric characters.
rules.name: Object name not recommended

rules.description:
*Checks for methods returning Unit that are defined without empty parentheses.*

Methods should be defined with empty parentheses if they have side effects. A method returning Unit must have side effects, therefore you should declare it with ().
rules.name: Parameterless methods returns unit

rules.description:
*Finds type bounds of the form [A <: Any] or [A >: Nothing].*

Type bound resolves to Nothing <: T <: Any. Did you mean to put in other bounds?
rules.name: Pointless type bounds

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Map().*

Map[K,V]() allocates an intermediate object. Consider Map.empty which returns a singleton instance without creating a new object.
rules.name: Prefer Map.empty

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Option.size.*

Prefer to use Option.isDefined, Option.isEmpty or Option.nonEmpty instead of Option.size.
rules.name: Prefer Option.isDefined instead of Option.size

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Seq().*

Seq[T]() allocates an intermediate object. Consider Seq.empty which returns a singleton instance without creating a new object.
rules.name: Prefer Seq.empty

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Set().*

Set[T]() allocates an intermediate object. Consider Set.empty which returns a singleton instance without creating a new object.
rules.name: Prefer Set.empty

rules.description:
*Checks for values that have Product with Serializable as their inferred type.*

It is unlikely that Product with Serializable was your target type. This is often an indication of mixing up incompatible types.
rules.name: Product with Serializable inferred

rules.description:
*Checks for overridden finalizes that are public.*

Public finalizer should be avoided as finalizers should not be programmatically invoked.
rules.name: PublicFinalizer

rules.description:
*Checks for redundant final modifiers on methods.*

A final modifier on methods that cannot be overridden is redundant.
rules.name: Redundant final modifier on a method

rules.description:
*Checks for redundant final modifier on vars.*

A final modifier on a var that cannot be overridden is redundant.
rules.name: Redundant final modifier on a var

rules.description:
*Checks for empty finalizers.*

An empty finalizer, e.g. override def finalize: Unit = {} is redundant and should be removed.
rules.name: Redundant finalizer

rules.description:
*Checks for the main branch and the else branch of an if being the same.*

The if statement could be refactored if both branches are the same or start with the same.
rules.name: Repeated body of if main and else branch

rules.description:
*Checks for case statements which have the same body.*

Case body is repeated. Consider merging pattern clauses together.
rules.name: Repeated case body

rules.description:
*Checks for boolean expressions that can be simplified.*

Boolean expressions such as x == false can be re-written as !x.
rules.name: Simplify boolean expressions

rules.description:
*Checks for String.substring(0).*

Use of String.substring(0) will always return the same string.
rules.name: String.substring(0)

rules.description:
*Checks for .stripMargin calls on regex strings that contain a pipe.*

Strip margin will strip | from regex - possible corrupted regex.
rules.name: Strip margin on regex

rules.description:
*Checks for code where matching is taking place on class literals.*

Matching on an companion object of a case class is probably not what you intended.
rules.name: Suspicious match on class object

rules.description:
*Checks for an inefficient use of filter.sort.*

Filter first and then sort the remaining collection. Swap sort.filter for filter.sort for better performance.
rules.name: Swap sort filter

rules.description:
*Checks for shadowed type parameters in methods.*

Shadowing type parameters is considered a bad practice and should be avoided.
rules.name: Type shadowing

rules.description:
*Checks for unnecessary toInt on instances of Int or toString on Strings, etc.*

Calling e.g. toString on a String or toList on a List is completely unnecessary and it's an equivalent to identity.
rules.name: Unnecessary conversion

rules.description:
*Checks for code like if (expr) true else false.*

If comparison is not needed. Use the condition, e.g. instead of if (a == b) true else false, use a == b or instead of if (a == b) false else true, use !(a == b).
rules.name: Unnecessary if condition.

rules.description:
*Checks for use of return keyword in blocks.*

Scala returns the value of the last expression in a block. Use of return here is not an idiomatic Scala.
rules.name: Unnecessary return

rules.description:
*Checks for use of reverse followed by head/headOption/iterator/map.*

reverse followed by head, headOption, iterator, or map can be replaced, respectively, with last, lastOption, reverseIterator, or reverseMap.
rules.name: Unnecessary reverse

rules.description:
*Checks for catch clauses that cannot be reached.*

One or more cases are unreachable.
rules.name: Unreachable catch

rules.description:
*Checks Seq.contains() and Option.contains() for unrelated types.*

contains() accepts arguments af any type, which means you might be checking if your collection contains an element of an unrelated type.
rules.name: Unsafe contains

rules.description:
*Checks for String.contains(value) for invalid types.*

String.contains() accepts arguments af any type, which means you might be checking if your string contains an element of an unrelated type.
rules.name: Unsafe string contains

rules.description:
*Checks for unused method parameters.*

Unused constructor or method parameters should be removed.
rules.name: Unused parameter

rules.description:
*Checks for use of math.pow for calculating math.cbrt.*

Use math.cbrt, which is clearer and more performant than math.pow(x, 1/3).
rules.name: Use cbrt

rules.description:
*Checks for use of math.exp(x) - 1 instead of math.expm1(x).*

Use math.expm1(x), which is clearer and more performant than math.exp(x) - 1.
rules.name: Use expm1

rules.description:
*Checks for use of math.log(x)/math.log(10) instead of math.log10(x).*

Use math.log10(x), which is clearer and more performant than $math.log(x)/$math.log(10).
rules.name: Use log10

rules.description:
*Checks for use of math.log(x + 1) instead of math.log1p(x)*

Use math.log1p(x) is clearer and more performant than $math.log(1 + x).
rules.name: Use log1p

rules.description:
*Checks for explicit toString calls on arrays.*

Calling toString on an array does not perform a deep toString.
rules.name: Use of Array.toString

rules.description:
*Checks for use of .get on Left or Right projection.*

Method .get on a Left and a Right projection in deprecated since 2.13, use Either.getOrElse or Either.swap.getOrElse instead.
rules.name: Use of Either.right or Either.left projection followed by a get

rules.description:
*Checks whether Map.get().getOrElse() can be simplified to Map.getOrElse().*

Map.get(key).getOrElse(value) can be replaced with Map.getOrElse(key, value), which is more concise.
rules.name: Use of Map.get().getOrElse instead of Map.getOrElse

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Option.get*

Using Option.get defeats the purpose of using Option in the first place. Use the following instead: Option.getOrElse, Option.fold, pattern matching or don't take the value out of the container and map over it to transform it.
rules.name: Use of Option.get

rules.description:
*Checks for use of Try.get.*

Using Try.get is unsafe because it will throw the underlying exception in case of a Failure. Use the following instead: Try.getOrElse, Try.fold, pattern matching or don't take the value out of the container and map over it to transform it.
rules.name: Use of Try.get

rules.description:
*Checks for indexing on a Seq which is not an IndexedSeq.*

Using an index to access elements of an IndexedSeq may cause performance problems.
rules.name: Use of apply method on a non-indexed Seq

rules.description:
**

Use of asInstanceOf is considered a bad practice - consider using pattern matching instead.
rules.name: Use of asInstanceOf

rules.description:
*Checks for use of isInstanceOf.*

Use of isInstanceOf is considered a bad practice - consider using pattern matching instead.
rules.name: Use of isInstanceOf

rules.description:
*Checks for use of unsafe methods on Traversable.*

The following methods on Traversable are considered to be unsafe (head, tail, init, last, reduce, reduceLeft, reduceRight, max, maxBy, min, minBy).
rules.name: Use of unsafe Traversable methods.

rules.description:
*Checks for use of math.pow for calculating math.sqrt.*

Use math.sqrt, which is clearer and more performant than $math.pow(x, 0.5).
rules.name: Use sqrt

rules.description:
*Checks for vars that could be declared as vals.*

A variable (var) that is never written to could be turned into a value (val).
rules.name: Var could be val

rules.description:
*Finds closures that reference variables (var).*

Closing over a var can lead to subtle bugs.
rules.name: Var in closure

rules.description:
*Checks for multiple uses of the variable name in nested scopes.*

Variable shadowing is very useful, but can easily lead to nasty bugs in your code. Shadowed variables can be potentially confusing to other maintainers when the same name is adopted to have a new meaning in a nested scope.
rules.name: Variable shadowing

rules.description:
*Checks for code that uses a while(true) or do {...} while(true) block.*

A (do) while true loop is unlikely to be meant for production.
rules.name: While true loop

rules.description:
*Checks for dividing 0 by a number.*

Dividing zero by any number will always return zero, e.g. 0 / x == 0.
rules.name: Zero numerator

rules.description:
*Checks for use of filter().head.*

filter().head can throw an exception if the collection is empty - it can be replaced with find() match {...}.
rules.name: filter().head can throw an exception

rules.description:
*Checks for use of filter().headOption.*

filter() scans the entire collection, which is unnecessary if you only want to get the first element that satisfies the predicate - filter().headOption can be replaced with find() to potentially avoid scanning the entire collection.
rules.name: filter().headOption instead of find()

rules.description:
*Checks for use of filter().isEmpty.*

filter() scans the entire collection, which can potentially be avoided if the element exists in the collection - filter().isEmpty can be replaced with !exists().
rules.name: filter().isEmpty instead of !exists()

rules.description:
*Checks if filter().size can be simplified to count().*

filter().size can be replaced with count(), which is more concise.
rules.name: filter().size() instead of count()

rules.description:
*Checks whether the expression can be rewritten using flatten.*

filter(_.isDefined).map(_.get) can be replaced with flatten.
rules.name: filter(_.isDefined).map(_.get) instead of flatten

rules.description:
*Checks whether find() can be replaced with exists().*

find().isDefined can be replaced with exists(), which is more concise.
rules.name: find().isDefined() instead of exists()

rules.description:
*Checks whether find() can be replaced with exists().*

find() != None can be replaced with exists(), which is more concise.
rules.name: find(x => ) != None instead of exists(x =>)

rules.description:
*Checks for use of reverse.tail.reverse.*

reverse.tail.reverse can be replaced with init, which is more concise.
rules.name: reverse.tail.reverse instead of init

rules.description:
*Checks for use of reverse.take().reverse.*

reverse.take().reverse can be replaced with takeRight, which is more concise.
rules.name: reverse.take().reverse instead of takeRight

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that block imports are not used.*

Block imports, e.g. `import a.{b, c}` can lead to annoying merge errors in large code bases that are maintained by lot of developers. This rule allows to ensure that only single imports are used in order to minimize merge errors in import declarations.
scalastyle.name: Avoid block imports

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that curlies imports are not used.*

Curlies imports, e.g. `import a.{b, c}`, can lead to annoying merge errors in large code bases that are maintained by lot of developers. This rule allows to ensure that only single imports, no renaming and no hiding imports are used in order to minimize merge errors in import declarations.
scalastyle.name: Avoid curlies imports

scalastyle.description:
*Avoid wildcard imports.*

Importing all classes from a package or static members from a class leads to tight coupling between packages or classes and might lead to problems when a new version of a library introduces name clashes.
scalastyle.name: Avoid wildcard imports

scalastyle.description:
*Check that class names match a regular expression.*

The Scala style guide recommends that class names conform to certain standards.
scalastyle.name: Class name

params.description: Regular expression: The class names must match this regular expression.
params.name: regex

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that type parameter to a class matches a regular expression.*

Scala generic type names are generally single upper case letters. This check checks for classes and traits. Note that this check only checks the innermost type parameter, to allow for `List[T]`.
scalastyle.name: Class type parameter name

params.description: Regular expression: Standard Scala regular expression syntax.
params.name: regex

scalastyle.description:
*Check that classes and objects do not define the clone() method.*

The clone method is difficult to get right. You can use the copy constructor of case classes rather than implementing clone. For more information on `clone()`, see Effective Java by Joshua Bloch pages.
scalastyle.name: Clone method

scalastyle.description:
*Check that classes and objects do not define equals without overriding equals(java.lang.Object).*

Mistakenly defining a covariant `equals()` method without overriding method `equals(java.lang.Object)` can produce unexpected runtime behaviour.
scalastyle.name: Covariant equals

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that the cyclomatic complexity of a method does exceed a value.*

If the code is too complex, then this can make code hard to read.
scalastyle.name: Cyclomatic complexity

params.description: Maximum: Maximum cyclomatic complexity to allow for a method.
params.name: maximum

params.description: Count Cases: If true, each case increases method complexity, else only match keyword is considered.
params.name: countCases

scalastyle.description:
*The interpolation for this string literal is not necessary.*

Empty interpolated strings are harder to read and not necessary.
scalastyle.name: Empty interpolated string

scalastyle.description:
*Check that if a class implements either equals or hashCode, it should implement the other.*

Defining either equals or hashCode in a class without defining the is a known source of bugs. Usually, when you define one, you should also define the other.
scalastyle.name: Equals hashCode

scalastyle.description:
*Check that field names match a regular expression.*

A consistent naming convention for field names can make code easier to read and understand.
scalastyle.name: Field name

params.description: Regular expression: The field names must match this regular expression.
params.name: regex

params.description: Regular expression for constants: The object field (constant) names must match this regular expression.
params.name: objectFieldRegex

scalastyle.description:
*Check the number of lines in a file.*

Files which are too long can be hard to read and understand.
scalastyle.name: File length

params.description: Maximum file length: Maximum number of lines in a file.
params.name: maxFileLength

scalastyle.description:
*Check the number of characters in a line.*

Lines that are too long can be hard to read and horizontal scrolling is annoying.
scalastyle.name: File line length

params.description: Maximum line length: Maximum number of characters in a line.
params.name: maxLineLength

params.description: Tab size: Number of characters that a tab represents.
params.name: tabSize

params.description: Ignore import statements: Ignore import statements.
params.name: ignoreImports

scalastyle.description:
*Check that classes and objects do not define the finalize() method.*

`finalize()` is called when the object is garbage collected, and garbage collection is not guaranteed to happen. It is therefore unwise to rely on code in `finalize()` method.
scalastyle.name: Finalize method

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that imports are grouped together, not throughout the file.*

If imports are spread throughout the file, knowing what is in scope at any one place can be difficult to work out.
scalastyle.name: Group imports

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that if statements have braces.*

Some people find if clauses with braces easier to read.

The `singleLineAllowed` property allows if constructions of the type:

```scala
if (bool_expression) expression1 else expression2
```

The `doubleLineAllowed` property allows if constructions of the type:

```scala
if (bool_expression) expression1 else expression2
```

Note: If you intend to enable only if expressions in the format below, disable the IfBraceChecker altogether.

```scala
if (bool_expression) expression1 else expression2
```
scalastyle.name: If block braces

params.description: Single Line Allowed: If without braces allowed if everything is on one line.
params.name: singleLineAllowed

params.description: Double Line Allowed: If without braces allowed if everything is on one line or two lines.
params.name: doubleLineAllowed

scalastyle.description:
*Check that a class does not import certain classes.*

Use of some classes can be discouraged for a project. For instance, use of `sun._` is generally discouraged because they are internal to the JDK and can be changed.
scalastyle.name: Illegal imports

params.description: Illegal Imports: The comma separated list of illegal imports, wildcards allowed.
params.name: illegalImports

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that imports are grouped and ordered according to the style configuration.*

Consistent import ordering improves code readability and reduces unrelated changes in patches.
scalastyle.name: Import Order

scalastyle.description:
*Check that there are no tabs in a file.*

Some say that tabs are evil.
scalastyle.name: Line contains Tab

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that argument literals are named.*

Nameless literals make code harder to understand (consider `updateEntity(1, true)` and `updateEntity(id = 1, enabled = true)`).
scalastyle.name: Literal passed as argument without name

params.description: Check string literals: If true, also checks that string literal arguments are named.
params.name: checkString

params.description: Ignore methods by pattern: Pattern to ignore method calls by name.
params.name: ignoreMethod

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that if a long literal is used, then an uppercase L is used.*

A lowercase L (l) can look similar to a number 1 with some fonts.
scalastyle.name: Long literal uppercase L

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that a case statement pattern match is not lower case, as this can cause confusion.*

A lower case pattern match clause with no other tokens is the same as `_`; this is not true for patterns which start with an upper case letter. This can cause confusion, and may not be what was intended:

```scala
val foo = "foo"
val Bar = "bar"
"bar" match { case Bar => "we got bar" } // result = "we got bar"
"bar" match { case foo => "we got foo" } // result = "we got foo"
"bar" match { case `foo` => "we got foo" } // result = MatchError
```

This checker raises a warning with the second match. To fix it, use an identifier which starts with an upper case letter (best), use `case _` or, if you wish to refer to the value, add a type `: Any`, e.g.:

```scala
val lc = "lc"
"something" match { case lc: Any => "lc" } // result = "lc"
"something" match { case _ => "lc" } // result = "lc"
```
scalastyle.name: Lowercase pattern match

scalastyle.description:
*Checks for use of magic numbers.*

Replacing a magic number with a named constant can make code easier to read and understand, and can avoid some subtle bugs.

A simple assignment to a val is not considered to be a magic number, for example: `val foo = 4` is not a magic number, but `var foo = 4` is considered to be a magic number.
scalastyle.name: Magic Number

params.description: Ignore: The comma separated list of numbers to ignore when used as magic numbers.
params.name: ignore

scalastyle.description:
*Check the first lines of each file matches the text.*

A lot of projects require a header with a copyright notice, or they require a license in each file. This does a simple text comparison between the header and the first lines of the file. You can have multiple lines, but make sure you surround the text with a `CDATA` section. You can also specify a regular expression, as long as you set the regex parameter to `true`.
scalastyle.name: Match Header

params.description: Header: The lines to compare against.
params.name: header

params.description: Header Regex: Whether to treat the header string as a regular expression.
params.name: regex

scalastyle.description:
*Maximum number of parameters for a method.*

A method which has more than a certain number of parameters can be hard to understand.
scalastyle.name: Maximum parameters

params.description: Maximum Number: The maximum number of parameters.
params.name: maxParameters

scalastyle.description:
*Check that method argument names match a regular expression.*

The Scala style guide recommends that method argument names conform to certain standards.
scalastyle.name: Method argument name

params.description: Regular expression: The method argument names must match this regular expression.
params.name: regex

params.description: Regular expression to ignore: Method argument names which match this regular expression will be ignored.
params.name: ignoreRegex

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that methods do not exceed a maximum length.*

Long methods can be hard to read and understand.
scalastyle.name: Method length

params.description: Maximum length: Maximum number of lines allowed for a method.
params.name: maxLength

params.description: Ignore comments: If set to true, comment lines in method body won't be counted.
params.name: ignoreComments

params.description: Ignore empty lines: If set to true, empty lines in method body won't be counted.
params.name: ignoreEmpty

scalastyle.description:
*Check that method names match a regular expression.*

The Scala style guide recommends that method names conform to certain standards. If the methods are overriding another method, and the overridden method cannot be changed, then use the `ignoreOverride` parameter.
scalastyle.name: Method name

params.description: Regular expression: The method names must match this regular expression.
params.name: regex

params.description: Regular expression to ignore: Method names which match this regular expression will be ignored.
params.name: ignoreRegex

params.description: Ignore override: If set to true, methods which have the override modifier are ignored.
params.name: ignoreOverride

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that the ScalaDoc on documentable members is well-formed.*

Scaladoc is generally considered a good thing. Within reason.

Ignore tokens is a comma separated string that may include the following: `PatDefOrDcl` (variables), `TmplDef` (classes, traits), `TypeDefOrDcl` (type definitions), `FunDefOrDcl` (functions). Supported indentation styles are "scaladoc" (for ScalaDoc-style comments, with two spaces before the asterisk), "javadoc" (for JavaDoc-style comments, with a single space before the asterisk) or "anydoc" to support any style (any number of spaces before the asterisk). For backwards compatibility, if left empty, "anydoc" will be assumed.
scalastyle.name: Missing or badly formed ScalaDoc

params.description: Regular expression: Class names matching this regular expression will be ignored.
params.name: ignoreRegex

params.description: Comma Separated String: Include the following to ignore : PatDefOrDcl (variables), TmplDef (classes, traits), TypeDefOrDcl (type definitions), FunDefOrDcl (functions).
params.name: ignoreTokenTypes

params.description: Ignore override: If set to true, methods which have the override modifier are ignored.
params.name: ignoreOverride

params.description: Force indent style: Possible values: scaladoc - 2 spaces before *, javadoc - 1 space before *.
params.name: indentStyle

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that a string literal does not appear multiple times.*

Code duplication makes maintenance more difficult, so it can be better to replace the multiple occurrences with a constant.
scalastyle.name: Multiple string literals

params.description: Maximum occurences allowed: Maximum number of occurences allowed.
params.name: allowed

params.description: Ignore regular expression: Regular expression to ignore.
params.name: ignoreRegex

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that a file ends with a newline character.*

Some version control systems don't cope well with files which don't end with a newline character.
scalastyle.name: Newline at EOF

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that a file does not end with a newline character.*

Because Mirco Dotta wanted it.
scalastyle.name: No Newline at EOF

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that classes and objects do not define mutable fields.*

`var` (mutable fields) are deprecated if you're using a strict functional style.
scalastyle.name: No mutable fields

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that functions do not define mutable variables.*

`var` (mutable local variables) are deprecated if you're using a strict functional style.
scalastyle.name: No mutable local variables

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that if expressions are not redundant, i.e. easily replaced by a variant of the condition.*

If expressions with boolean constants in both branches can be eliminated without affecting readability. Prefer simply `cond` to `if (cond) true else false` and `!cond` to `if (cond) false else true`.
scalastyle.name: No redundant if expressions

scalastyle.description:
*Ensure single space after certain token(s).*

Correct formatting can help readability.
scalastyle.name: No space after tokens

scalastyle.description:
*Ensure single space before certain token(s).*

Correct formatting can help readability.
scalastyle.name: No space before tokens

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that Java @Deprecated is not used, Scala @deprecated should be used instead.*

You should be using the Scala `@deprecated` instead.
scalastyle.name: No use of Java @Deprecated

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that Java @Override is not used.*

You should be using the Scala override keyword instead.
scalastyle.name: No use of Java @Override

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that while is not used.*

`while` loops are deprecated if you're using a strict functional style.
scalastyle.name: No while loops

scalastyle.description:
*No whitespace after left bracket ''[''.*

If there is whitespace after a left bracket, this can be confusing to the reader.
scalastyle.name: No whitespace after left bracket ''[''

scalastyle.description:
*No whitespace before left bracket ''[''.*

If there is whitespace before a left bracket, this can be confusing to the reader.
scalastyle.name: No whitespace before left bracket ''[''

scalastyle.description:
*No whitespace before right bracket '']''.*

If there is whitespace before a right bracket, this can be confusing to the reader.
scalastyle.name: No whitespace before right bracket '']''

scalastyle.description:
*Some editors are unfriendly to non ASCII characters.*

Scala allows unicode characters as operators and some editors misbehave when they see non-ascii character. In a project collaborated by a community of developers. This check can be helpful in such situations. 

```scala
"value" match {
  case "value" => println("matched")
  ...
}
```

is preferred to

```scala
"value" match {
  case "value"  println("matched")
  ...
}
```

To fix it, replace the (unicode operator) `` with `=>`.
scalastyle.name: Non ASCII characters are not allowed

params.description: Allow non-ASCII scripts in string literals.: White lists Unicode characters recognized by `\p'{'Alnum'}'\p'{'Punct'}'\p'{'Sc'}'\p'{'Space'}'` but not symbols like Emoji.
params.name: allowStringLiterals

scalastyle.description:
*Check that null is not used.*

Scala discourages use of `null`, preferring `Option`.
scalastyle.name: Null

params.description: Allow null checks: Allow occurrences in checks like 'x == null' or 'x != null'.
params.name: allowNullChecks

scalastyle.description:
*Check that a class / trait / object does not have too many methods.*

If a type declares too many methods, this can be an indication of bad design.
scalastyle.name: Number of methods in type

params.description: Maximum methods: The maximum number of methods allowed.
params.name: maxMethods

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that there are not too many types declared in a file.*

If there are too many classes/objects defined in a single file, this can cause the code to be difficult to understand.
scalastyle.name: Number of types

params.description: Maximum Number: Maximum number of types to allow.
params.name: maxTypes

scalastyle.description:
*Check that object names match a regular expression.*

The Scala style guide recommends that object names conform to certain standards.
scalastyle.name: Object name

params.description: Regular expression: The object names must match this regular expression.
params.name: regex

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that braces aren't used in case clauses.*

Braces aren't required in case clauses. They should be omitted according to Scala Style Guide.
scalastyle.name: Omit braces in case clauses

scalastyle.description:
*Check that package names match a regular expression.*

The Scala style guide recommends that package names conform to certain standards.
scalastyle.name: Package name

params.description: Regular expression: The package names must match this regular expression.
params.name: regex

scalastyle.description:
*Check that package object names match a regular expression.*

The Scala style guide recommends that package object names conform to certain standards.
scalastyle.name: Package object name

params.description: Regular expression: The package object names must match this regular expression.
params.name: regex

scalastyle.description:
*Check that pattern match arrows align.*

Correct formatting can help readability.
scalastyle.name: Pattern match align

scalastyle.description:
*Check that a method has an explicit return type, it is not inferred.*

A public method declared on a type is effectively an API declaration. Explicitly declaring a return type means that other code which depends on that type won't break unexpectedly.
scalastyle.name: Public method must have type

params.description: Ignore overridden methods: If true, public methods which override are ignored.
params.name: ignoreOverride

scalastyle.description:
*If a class/trait has no members, the braces are unnecessary.*

If a `class` / `trait` has no members, then braces are unnecessary, and can be removed.
scalastyle.name: Redundant braces in class definition

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that a regular expression cannot be matched, if found reports this.*

Some checks can be carried out with a regular expression.
scalastyle.name: Regular expression

params.description: Regular expression: Standard Scala regular expression syntax including multiline.
params.name: regex

params.description: Line: Boolean whether to process line by line.
params.name: line

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that a regular expression cannot be matched in a token, if found reports this.*

Some checks can be carried by just the presence of a particular token.
scalastyle.name: Regular expression in a token

params.description: Regular expression: Standard Scala regular expression syntax.
params.name: regex

scalastyle.description:
*Check that return is not used.*

Use of `return` is not usually necessary in Scala. In fact, use of return can discourage a functional style of programming.
scalastyle.name: Return

scalastyle.description:
*Boolean expression can be simplified.*

A boolean expression which can be simplified can make code easier to read.
scalastyle.name: Simplify Boolean expression

scalastyle.description:
*Check that the plus sign is followed by a space.*

An expression with spaces around `+` can be easier to read.
scalastyle.name: Space after plus

scalastyle.description:
*Checks a space after the start of the comment.*

To bring consistency with how comments should be formatted, leave a space right after the beginning of the comment.

```scala
package foobar

object Foobar {
  /**WRONG
    *
    */
  /** Correct
    *
    */
  val d = 2 /*Wrong*/ //Wrong
  /**
    * Correct
    */
  val e = 3 /** Correct*/ // Correct
}
```
scalastyle.name: Space after the start of the comment

scalastyle.description:
*Disallow space after certain token(s).*

Correct formatting can help readability.
scalastyle.name: Space after tokens

scalastyle.description:
*Check that the plus sign is preceded by a space.*

An expression with spaces around `+` can be easier to read.
scalastyle.name: Space before plus

scalastyle.description:
*Disallow space before certain token(s).*

Correct formatting can help readability.
scalastyle.name: Space before tokens

scalastyle.description:
*Check that structural types are not used.*

Structural types in Scala can use reflection - this can have unexpected performance consequences. Warning: This check can also wrongly pick up type lamdbas and other such constructs. This checker should be used with care. You always have the alternative of the scalac checking for structural types.
scalastyle.name: Structural type

scalastyle.description:
*Check for use of TODO/FIXME single line comments.*

Some projects may consider `TODO` or `FIXME` comments in a code bad style. They would rather you fix the problem.
scalastyle.name: TODO/FIXME comment

params.description: Word list: Alternative list of words to look for, separated by |.
params.name: words

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that the code does not have ??? operators.*

The `???` operator denotes that an implementation is missing. This rule helps to avoid potential runtime errors because of not implemented code.
scalastyle.name: Usage of ??? operator

scalastyle.description:
*Use a : Unit = for procedure declarations.*

A procedure style declaration can cause confusion - the developer may have simply forgotten to add a `=`, and now their method returns `Unit` rather than the inferred type:

```scala
def foo() { println("hello"); 5 }
```
This checker raises a warning with the first line. To fix it, use an explicit return type, or add a `=` before the body.

```scala
def foo() = { println("hello"); 5 }
```
scalastyle.name: Use : Unit = for procedures

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that braces are used in for comprehensions.*

Usage of braces (rather than parentheses) within a `for` comprehension mean that you don't have to specify a semi-colon at the end of every line:

```scala
for { // braces
  t <- List(1,2,3)
  if (t % 2 == 0)
} yield t
```

is preferred to

```scala
for ( // parentheses
  t <- List(1,2,3);
  if (t % 2 == 0)
) yield t
```

To fix it, replace the `()` with `{}`. And then remove the `;` at the end of the lines.

The `singleLineAllowed` property allows for constructions of the type:

```scala
for (i <- List(1,2,3)) yield i
```
scalastyle.name: Use braces in for comprehensions

params.description: Allow parentheses for single-line for: For with parentheses allowed if everything is on one line.
params.name: singleLineAllowed

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that lines are indented by a multiple of the tab size.*

Code that is not indented consistently can be hard to read.
scalastyle.name: Use correct indentation

params.description: Tab size: Number of characters that a tab represents.
params.name: tabSize

params.description: Multi-line method parameter spacing: Level of indentation of multi-line method parameters relative to the indentation of the first line of the method.
params.name: methodParamIndentSize

params.description: Multi-line class parameter spacing: Level of indentation of multi-line primary constructor parameters of a class. Relative to the indentation of the first line of class declaration.
params.name: classParamIndentSize

scalastyle.name: Use parentheses in for loops

scalastyle.description:
*Checks that while body have braces.*

While cannot be used in a pure-functional manner, that's why it's recommended to never omit braces according to Scala Style Guide.
scalastyle.name: While body should have braces

scalastyle.description:
*Check that there is no trailing whitespace at the end of lines.*

Whitespace at the end of a line can cause problems when diffing between files or between versions.
scalastyle.name: Whitespace at end of line

params.description: Ignore lines with just whitespace: Skip a line if the entire contents are whitespace characters.
params.name: ignoreWhitespaceLines

scalastyle.description:
*Check that XML literals are not used.*

Some projects prefer not to have XML literals. They could use a templating engine instead.
scalastyle.name: XML literals

scapegoat.description:
*Checks whether !isEmpty can be replaced with nonEmpty.*

!.isEmpty can be replaced with.nonEmpty to make it easier to reason about.
scapegoat.name: !isEmpty can be replaced with nonEmpty

scapegoat.description:
*Checks whether !nonEmpty can be replaced with isEmpty.*

!.nonEmpty can be replaced with.isEmpty to make it easier to reason about.
scapegoat.name: !nonEmpty can be replaced with isEmpty

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for comparison of arrays using == which will always return false.*

Array equals is not an equality check. Use a.deep == b.deep or convert to another collection type.
scapegoat.name: Array equals

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for arrays passed to String.format.*

An Array passed to String.format might result in an incorrect formatting.
scapegoat.name: Array passed to String.format

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for ranges using (j to k - 1).*

A range in the following format (j to k - 1) can be simplified to (j until k).
scapegoat.name: Avoid (j to k - 1)

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Traversable.size.*

.size can be slow for some data structures, prefer .nonEmpty, which is O(1).
scapegoat.name: Avoid Traversable.size != 0

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Traversable.size.*

Traversable.size can be slow for some data structures, prefer Traversable.isEmpty, which is O(1).
scapegoat.name: Avoid Traversable.size == 0

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for symbolic method names.*

Scala style guide advocates against routinely using operators as method names, see http://docs.scala-lang.org/style/naming-conventions.html#symbolic-method-names.
scapegoat.name: Avoid operator overload

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of BigDecimal(double) which can be unsafe.*

The results of this constructor can be somewhat unpredictable. E.g. writing new BigDecimal(0.1) in Java creates a BigDecimal which is actually equal to 0.1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This is because 0.1 cannot be represented exactly as a double.
scapegoat.name: Big decimal double constructor

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of setScale() on a BigDecimal without setting the rounding mode can throw an exception.*

When using setScale() on a BigDecimal without setting the rounding mode, this can throw an exception if rounding is required. Did you mean to call setScale(s, RoundingMode.XYZ)?
scapegoat.name: BigDecimal setScale() without rounding mode

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for types with upper bounds of a final type.*

Pointless type bound. Type parameter can only be a single value.
scapegoat.name: Bounded by a final type

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for potentially broken odd checks.*

Code that attempts to check for oddness using x % 2 == 1 will fail on negative numbers. Consider using x % 2 != 0
scapegoat.name: Broken odd check

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for try blocks that catch exception.*

Did you intend to catch all exceptions? Consider catching a more specific exception class.
scapegoat.name: Catch exception

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for try blocks that catch fatal exceptions: VirtualMachineError, ThreadDeath, InterruptedException, LinkageError, ControlThrowable.*

Did you intend to catch a fatal exception? Consider using scala.util.control.NonFatal instead.
scapegoat.name: Catch fatal exception

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for try blocks that catch Throwable.*

Did you intend to catch all throwables? Consider catching a more specific exception class.
scapegoat.name: Catch throwable

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for try blocks that catch null pointer exceptions.*

Avoid using null at all cost and you shouldn't need to catch NullPointerExceptions. Prefer Option to indicate potentially missing values and use Try to materialize exceptions thrown by any external libraries.
scapegoat.name: Catching NPE

scapegoat.description:
*Ensures class names adhere to the style guidelines.*

Class names should begin with uppercase letter.
scapegoat.name: Class name not recommended

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for negative access on a sequence, e.g. list.get(-1).*

Trying to access Seq elements using a negative index will result in an IndexOutOfBoundsException.
scapegoat.name: Collection index out of bounds

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for variables that are confusingly named.*

E.g. an instance of a Set is confusingly referred to by a variable called/containing list, or the other way around.
scapegoat.name: Collection naming confusion

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for collection operations that promote the collection to Any.*

The :+ (append) operator on collections accepts any argument you give it, which means that you can end up with e.g. Seq[Any] if your types don't match.
scapegoat.name: Collection promotion to Any

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for equality comparisons that cannot succeed.*

In most case comparing unrelated types cannot succeed and it's usually an indication of a bug.
scapegoat.name: Comparing unrelated types

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for equality checks with itself.*

Comparison with self will always yield true.
scapegoat.name: Comparision with self

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code like a == List() or a == Nil.*

Prefer use of isEmpty instead of comparison to an empty List.
scapegoat.name: Comparison to empty list

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code like a == Set() or a == Set.empty.*

Prefer use of isEmpty instead of comparison to an empty Set.
scapegoat.name: Comparison to empty set

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code where the if condition compiles to a constant.*

An if condition which gets compiled to a constant, like e.g. if (1 < 2) or if (false) doesn't add any value and should be avoided.
scapegoat.name: Constant if expression

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for division by one.*

Divide by one will always return the original value.
scapegoat.name: Divide by one

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code like !(!b).*

Double negation can be removed, e.g. !(!b) it equal to just b.
scapegoat.name: Double negation

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for duplicate import statements.*

Duplicate imports should be removed.
scapegoat.name: Duplicate import

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for duplicate key names in Map literals.*

A map key is overwritten by a later entry.
scapegoat.name: Duplicated map key

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for duplicate values in set literals.*

A set value is overwritten by a later entry.
scapegoat.name: Duplicated set value

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for empty case classes like, e.g. case class Faceman().*

An empty case class can be rewritten as a case object.
scapegoat.name: Empty case class

scapegoat.description:
*Finds catch blocks that don't handle caught exceptions.*

If you use a try/catch block to deal with an exception, you should handle all of the caught exceptions and if for some reason you're throwing another exception in the result, you should include the original exception as the cause.
scapegoat.name: Empty catch block

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for empty for loops.*

An empty for loop isn't a common practice and in most cases is considered as dead code.
scapegoat.name: Empty for loop

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for empty if blocks.*

An empty if block is considered as dead code.
scapegoat.name: Empty if expression

scapegoat.description:
*Looks for interpolated strings that have no arguments.*

String declared as interpolated but has no parameters can be turned into a regular string.
scapegoat.name: Empty interpolated string

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for empty method statements.*

An empty method is considered as dead code.
scapegoat.name: Empty method

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for empty synchronized blocks.*

An empty synchronized block is considered as dead code.
scapegoat.name: Empty synchronized block

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for empty try blocks.*

An empty try block is considered as dead code.
scapegoat.name: Empty try block

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for empty while blocks.*

An empty while block is considered as dead code.
scapegoat.name: Empty while block

scapegoat.description:
*Checks if exists() can be simplified to contains().*

exists(x => x == y) can be replaced with contains(y).
scapegoat.name: Exists simplifiable to contains

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for overridden finalizers that do not call super.*

Finalizers should call super.finalize() to ensure superclasses are able to run their finalization logic.
scapegoat.name: Finalizer without super

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for equality checks on floating point types.*

Due to minor rounding errors, it is not advisable to compare floating-point numbers using the == operator. Either use a threshold based comparison, or switch to a BigDecimal.
scapegoat.name: Floating type comparison

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for invalid format strings.*

An unchecked exception will be thrown when a format string contains an illegal syntax or a format specifier that is incompatible with the given arguments.
scapegoat.name: Illegal format string

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code like option.size > 1.*

Option.size > 1 can never be true, did you mean to use Option.nonEmpty instead?
scapegoat.name: Impossible Option.size condition

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for wrong number of arguments to String.format.*

The number of arguments passed to String.format doesn't correspond to the number of fields in the format string.
scapegoat.name: Incorrect number of args for format

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for exceptions that are not called *Exception and vice versa.*

Class named exception does not derive from Exception / class derived from Exception is not named *Exception.
scapegoat.name: Incorrectly named exceptions

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for expressions like x % 1.*

Any expression x % 1 will always return 0.
scapegoat.name: Integer mod one

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for invalid regex literals.*

Invalid regex literals can fail at compile time with a PatternSyntaxException. This could be caused by e.g. dangling meta characters, or unclosed escape characters, etc.
scapegoat.name: Invalid regex

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Java conversions.*

Use of Java conversions can lead to unusual behaviour. It is recommended to use JavaConverters.
scapegoat.name: Java conversions

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for when elements are appended to a list.*

List append is O(n). For large lists, consider using cons (::) or another data structure such as ListBuffer, Vector or a cats.data.Chain (which has constant prepend and append).
scapegoat.name: List append is slow

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of List.size.*

List.size is O(n). Consider using a different data type with O(1) size lookup such as Vector or an Array.
scapegoat.name: List.size is O(n)

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for sealed traits without any classes extending it.*

A sealed trait that is not extended is considered dead code.
scapegoat.name: Lonely sealed trait

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for strings that look like they should be interpolated.*

Did you forget to prefix this string with an s, f or raw to interpolate it?
scapegoat.name: Looks like interpolated String

scapegoat.description:
*Warns when you could use a partial function directly instead of a match block.*

A map match can be replaced with a partial function for greater readability.
scapegoat.name: Match instead of a partial function

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for methods that have over 10 parameters.*

Methods having a large number of parameters are more difficult to reason about, consider refactoring this code.
scapegoat.name: Max parameters

scapegoat.description:
*Warns on method names that don't adhere to the Scala style guidelines.*

Methods should be in camelCase style with the first letter lower-case. See http://docs.scala-lang.org/style/naming-conventions.html#methods.
scapegoat.name: Method name not recommended

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for functions that are defined or inferred to return Any.*

Method returns Any. Consider using a more specialized type.
scapegoat.name: Method returning Any

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for case classes without a final modifier.*

Using case classes without final modifier can lead to surprising breakage.
scapegoat.name: Missing final modifier on case class

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for x == Double.NaN which will always fail.*

NaN comparison will always fail. Use value.isNan instead.
scapegoat.name: Nan comparison

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code that overrides parent method but simply calls super.*

This method is overridden yet only calls super.
scapegoat.name: Noop override

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of null in assignments.*

Use an Option instead when the value can be empty.
scapegoat.name: Null assignment

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of null in method invocation.*

Use an Option instead when the value can be empty and pass down a None instead.
scapegoat.name: Null parameter

scapegoat.description:
*Ensures object names adhere to the Scala style guidelines.*

Object names should only contain alphanumeric characters.
scapegoat.name: Object name not recommended

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for methods returning Unit that are defined without empty parentheses.*

Methods should be defined with empty parentheses if they have side effects. A method returning Unit must have side effects, therefore you should declare it with ().
scapegoat.name: Parameterless methods returns unit

scapegoat.description:
*Finds type bounds of the form [A <: Any] or [A >: Nothing].*

Type bound resolves to Nothing <: T <: Any. Did you mean to put in other bounds?
scapegoat.name: Pointless type bounds

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Map().*

Map[K,V]() allocates an intermediate object. Consider Map.empty which returns a singleton instance without creating a new object.
scapegoat.name: Prefer Map.empty

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Option.size.*

Prefer to use Option.isDefined, Option.isEmpty or Option.nonEmpty instead of Option.size.
scapegoat.name: Prefer Option.isDefined instead of Option.size

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Seq().*

Seq[T]() allocates an intermediate object. Consider Seq.empty which returns a singleton instance without creating a new object.
scapegoat.name: Prefer Seq.empty

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Set().*

Set[T]() allocates an intermediate object. Consider Set.empty which returns a singleton instance without creating a new object.
scapegoat.name: Prefer Set.empty

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for values that have Product with Serializable as their inferred type.*

It is unlikely that Product with Serializable was your target type. This is often an indication of mixing up incompatible types.
scapegoat.name: Product with Serializable inferred

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for overridden finalizes that are public.*

Public finalizer should be avoided as finalizers should not be programmatically invoked.
scapegoat.name: PublicFinalizer

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for redundant final modifiers on methods.*

A final modifier on methods that cannot be overridden is redundant.
scapegoat.name: Redundant final modifier on a method

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for redundant final modifier on vars.*

A final modifier on a var that cannot be overridden is redundant.
scapegoat.name: Redundant final modifier on a var

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for empty finalizers.*

An empty finalizer, e.g. override def finalize: Unit = {} is redundant and should be removed.
scapegoat.name: Redundant finalizer

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for the main branch and the else branch of an if being the same.*

The if statement could be refactored if both branches are the same or start with the same.
scapegoat.name: Repeated body of if main and else branch

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for case statements which have the same body.*

Case body is repeated. Consider merging pattern clauses together.
scapegoat.name: Repeated case body

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for boolean expressions that can be simplified.*

Boolean expressions such as x == false can be re-written as !x.
scapegoat.name: Simplify boolean expressions

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for String.substring(0).*

Use of String.substring(0) will always return the same string.
scapegoat.name: String.substring(0)

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for .stripMargin calls on regex strings that contain a pipe.*

Strip margin will strip | from regex - possible corrupted regex.
scapegoat.name: Strip margin on regex

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code where matching is taking place on class literals.*

Matching on an companion object of a case class is probably not what you intended.
scapegoat.name: Suspicious match on class object

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for an inefficient use of filter.sort.*

Filter first and then sort the remaining collection. Swap sort.filter for filter.sort for better performance.
scapegoat.name: Swap sort filter

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for shadowed type parameters in methods.*

Shadowing type parameters is considered a bad practice and should be avoided.
scapegoat.name: Type shadowing

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for unnecessary toInt on instances of Int or toString on Strings, etc.*

Calling e.g. toString on a String or toList on a List is completely unnecessary and it's an equivalent to identity.
scapegoat.name: Unnecessary conversion

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code like if (expr) true else false.*

If comparison is not needed. Use the condition, e.g. instead of if (a == b) true else false, use a == b or instead of if (a == b) false else true, use !(a == b).
scapegoat.name: Unnecessary if condition.

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of return keyword in blocks.*

Scala returns the value of the last expression in a block. Use of return here is not an idiomatic Scala.
scapegoat.name: Unnecessary return

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of reverse followed by head/headOption/iterator/map.*

reverse followed by head, headOption, iterator, or map can be replaced, respectively, with last, lastOption, reverseIterator, or reverseMap.
scapegoat.name: Unnecessary reverse

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for catch clauses that cannot be reached.*

One or more cases are unreachable.
scapegoat.name: Unreachable catch

scapegoat.description:
*Checks Seq.contains() and Option.contains() for unrelated types.*

contains() accepts arguments af any type, which means you might be checking if your collection contains an element of an unrelated type.
scapegoat.name: Unsafe contains

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for String.contains(value) for invalid types.*

String.contains() accepts arguments af any type, which means you might be checking if your string contains an element of an unrelated type.
scapegoat.name: Unsafe string contains

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for unused method parameters.*

Unused constructor or method parameters should be removed.
scapegoat.name: Unused parameter

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of math.pow for calculating math.cbrt.*

Use math.cbrt, which is clearer and more performant than math.pow(x, 1/3).
scapegoat.name: Use cbrt

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of math.exp(x) - 1 instead of math.expm1(x).*

Use math.expm1(x), which is clearer and more performant than math.exp(x) - 1.
scapegoat.name: Use expm1

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of math.log(x)/math.log(10) instead of math.log10(x).*

Use math.log10(x), which is clearer and more performant than $math.log(x)/$math.log(10).
scapegoat.name: Use log10

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of math.log(x + 1) instead of math.log1p(x)*

Use math.log1p(x) is clearer and more performant than $math.log(1 + x).
scapegoat.name: Use log1p

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for explicit toString calls on arrays.*

Calling toString on an array does not perform a deep toString.
scapegoat.name: Use of Array.toString

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of .get on Left or Right projection.*

Method .get on a Left and a Right projection in deprecated since 2.13, use Either.getOrElse or Either.swap.getOrElse instead.
scapegoat.name: Use of Either.right or Either.left projection followed by a get

scapegoat.description:
*Checks whether Map.get().getOrElse() can be simplified to Map.getOrElse().*

Map.get(key).getOrElse(value) can be replaced with Map.getOrElse(key, value), which is more concise.
scapegoat.name: Use of Map.get().getOrElse instead of Map.getOrElse

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Option.get*

Using Option.get defeats the purpose of using Option in the first place. Use the following instead: Option.getOrElse, Option.fold, pattern matching or don't take the value out of the container and map over it to transform it.
scapegoat.name: Use of Option.get

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of Try.get.*

Using Try.get is unsafe because it will throw the underlying exception in case of a Failure. Use the following instead: Try.getOrElse, Try.fold, pattern matching or don't take the value out of the container and map over it to transform it.
scapegoat.name: Use of Try.get

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for indexing on a Seq which is not an IndexedSeq.*

Using an index to access elements of an IndexedSeq may cause performance problems.
scapegoat.name: Use of apply method on a non-indexed Seq

scapegoat.description:
**

Use of asInstanceOf is considered a bad practice - consider using pattern matching instead.
scapegoat.name: Use of asInstanceOf

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of isInstanceOf.*

Use of isInstanceOf is considered a bad practice - consider using pattern matching instead.
scapegoat.name: Use of isInstanceOf

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of unsafe methods on Traversable.*

The following methods on Traversable are considered to be unsafe (head, tail, init, last, reduce, reduceLeft, reduceRight, max, maxBy, min, minBy).
scapegoat.name: Use of unsafe Traversable methods.

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of math.pow for calculating math.sqrt.*

Use math.sqrt, which is clearer and more performant than $math.pow(x, 0.5).
scapegoat.name: Use sqrt

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for vars that could be declared as vals.*

A variable (var) that is never written to could be turned into a value (val).
scapegoat.name: Var could be val

scapegoat.description:
*Finds closures that reference variables (var).*

Closing over a var can lead to subtle bugs.
scapegoat.name: Var in closure

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for multiple uses of the variable name in nested scopes.*

Variable shadowing is very useful, but can easily lead to nasty bugs in your code. Shadowed variables can be potentially confusing to other maintainers when the same name is adopted to have a new meaning in a nested scope.
scapegoat.name: Variable shadowing

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for code that uses a while(true) or do {...} while(true) block.*

A (do) while true loop is unlikely to be meant for production.
scapegoat.name: While true loop

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for dividing 0 by a number.*

Dividing zero by any number will always return zero, e.g. 0 / x == 0.
scapegoat.name: Zero numerator

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of filter().head.*

filter().head can throw an exception if the collection is empty - it can be replaced with find() match {...}.
scapegoat.name: filter().head can throw an exception

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of filter().headOption.*

filter() scans the entire collection, which is unnecessary if you only want to get the first element that satisfies the predicate - filter().headOption can be replaced with find() to potentially avoid scanning the entire collection.
scapegoat.name: filter().headOption instead of find()

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of filter().isEmpty.*

filter() scans the entire collection, which can potentially be avoided if the element exists in the collection - filter().isEmpty can be replaced with !exists().
scapegoat.name: filter().isEmpty instead of !exists()

scapegoat.description:
*Checks if filter().size can be simplified to count().*

filter().size can be replaced with count(), which is more concise.
scapegoat.name: filter().size() instead of count()

scapegoat.description:
*Checks whether the expression can be rewritten using flatten.*

filter(_.isDefined).map(_.get) can be replaced with flatten.
scapegoat.name: filter(_.isDefined).map(_.get) instead of flatten

scapegoat.description:
*Checks whether find() can be replaced with exists().*

find().isDefined can be replaced with exists(), which is more concise.
scapegoat.name: find().isDefined() instead of exists()

scapegoat.description:
*Checks whether find() can be replaced with exists().*

find() != None can be replaced with exists(), which is more concise.
scapegoat.name: find(x => ) != None instead of exists(x =>)

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of reverse.tail.reverse.*

reverse.tail.reverse can be replaced with init, which is more concise.
scapegoat.name: reverse.tail.reverse instead of init

scapegoat.description:
*Checks for use of reverse.take().reverse.*

reverse.take().reverse can be replaced with takeRight, which is more concise.
scapegoat.name: reverse.take().reverse instead of takeRight
